description.value:
Ankhrub, Ankhrush, and Ankhepri

Element Life

Attribute Modifiers Str +1, Dex +2, Con +3, Int +0, Wis +4, Cha -1

Eldamon Language Jyoti

Eldamon Hit Points 8

Eldamon Skills Acrobatics, Athletics, Survival

Eldamon Saving Throw Fortitude

Senses low-light vision

Resistance light, vitality (since it isn’t undead, it can’t normally be harmed by vitality)

Weaknesses darkness, death, shadow

Speed 25 feet

Melee 1 horn (agile, finesse; reach 10 feet when evolved only); Damage 1d4 piercing plus 1 additional vitality (1d6 piercing plus 1 additional vitality when evolved only)

Evolution Condition Helping ankhrub collect good luck and health schemes that actually work.

Elemental Ability @UUID[Compendium.battlezoo-eldamon-pf2e.eldamon-features.Item.h9QCIWKzR1T7SQYT]{Scarab of Protection} The life energies within you protect you from the forces of poison, death, and disease. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to saving throws against poison, death, and disease effects. If you roll a success on a saving throw against a death effect, you get a critical success instead.

Form Ability @UUID[Compendium.battlezoo-eldamon-pf2e.eldamon-features.Item.PWSnkuaoOWMQhouT]{Flutter Jump} Your wings might not be enough to fly, but they help you jump farther. You can High Jump or Long Jump as a single action without a running start, and the distance is doubled (though this still doesn’t allow you to jump farther than your Speed).

Evolution Ability @UUID[Compendium.battlezoo-eldamon-pf2e.eldamon-features.Item.TxHO0F1gmNWhrVpX]{All the Luck Charms} When you would be affected by a misfortune effect, one of your many luck charms averts misfortune; this is a fortune effect, but it doesn’t do anything but negate the misfortune effect. Afterward, you can’t benefit from this ability for 1 round.

Attribute Modifier Progression

Advanced Training (5th) Str +2, Dex +3, Con +3, Int +1, Wis +4, Cha +0

Eldamon Evolution (11th) Str +2, Dex +4, Con +4, Int +1, Wis +5, Cha +0

Apex Training (15th) Str +3, Dex +4, Con +5, Int +2, Wis +5, Cha +1

Final Attribute Boost (17th) Str +3, Dex +4, Con +5, Int +2, Wis +6, Cha +1
This eldamon class item is added automatically to eldamon when adding the ancestry.

You rearrange the elemental energies around you, refreshing your powers. You refresh all your active and reactive powers, allowing you to use them all again.

Special The Refresh activity gains your element's associated traits.

Requirements You haven't used a power or elemental surge yet this turn

You create a minor surge of your element in place of using a power. You can't use a power on this turn, but on your next turn, the first time you use an active power, you gain the elemental surge effect based on your element, just before or just after applying the power's normal effects (your choice). If the effect specifies that it affects a creature, it affects one creature of your choice that's either you, a target of your power, or a creature in the power's area. If the effect specifies that it affects you, you gain the benefit.

The eldamon has resistances and weaknesses to the listed damage types and traits equal to their level. The resistance and weakness are based on their element, so it will rarely vary between eldamon of the same element.
This eldamon has a mortal friend.

Eldamon have innate defenses from their elements that protect them from harm, akin to armor for mortals. This grants them a +2 item bonus to AC and a +3 Maximum Dexterity. Additionally, an eldamon with a mortal friend (whether or not they're an eldamon trainer) can share their friend's armor potency rune and resilient rune, granting them an increased item bonus to AC and an item bonus to saving throws

The element of life embodies birth, healing rebirth, and the vital essence that permeates all living creatures, giving them their instincts, intuition, and collective faith. Life users focus on preservation and rejuvenation, mainly via temporary Hit Points, keeping themselves and their allies healthy and refreshed no matter the threat.

Vital Resurgence: Your temporary Hit Points are full of resurgent life energy. If a creature has 0 Hit Points and gains temporary Hit Points from your life power, they regain 1 Hit Point. Once per hour, instead of granting temporary Hit Points with your life power, you can choose to heal a creature for an equal amount of Hit Points; the creature then becomes temporarily immune to this substitution for 1 hour.

Associated Damage Type: Vitality

Associated Traits: Vitality

Life Key Terms

You'll see the following term in several life elemental powers.

Recovery: A recovery effect is a healing effect that recovers from a particular damage source. Recover effects often happen simultaneously to a damage source, effectively reducing the damage. A recovery effect can never heal more damage than the amount of actual Hit Points (not temporary Hit Points) the creature loses from the linked damage source, even if several recovery effects happen at once. When the healing is simultaneous to the damage, it can potentially prevent the healed creature from being reduced to 0 Hit Points and becoming unconscious, though if the remaining damage is still enough to knock them unconscious, the healing doesn't wake them up. Recovery effects that happen at a different timing can wake a creature from being unconscious as normal, though they still can't heal a creature more than the amount of actual Hit Points they lost, even in combination with other recovery effects.

Other Abilities

If your element is life, you gain the following abilities and effects from the Elemental Surge action, the Elemental Shield action, and the elemental avatar feats that vary by element.

Elemental Locomotion You can transmit yourself through a creature's life force in order to move through its space. As a single action, which has the move trait, you move through an adjacent living creature's space, even if they're a foe, to any other space adjacent to that creature. This movement doesn't trigger reactions based on movement.

Elemental Manipulation When you use Elemental Manipulation, you can send waves of life into a dying creature within 30 feet in order to stabilize them. The creature loses the dying condition, though it remains unconscious at 0 Hit Points. Additionally, you can use Medicine without a healer's kit as long as you have a hand free, receiving a +1 item bonus to your Medicine check when you do so at 3rd level, a +2 item bonus at 9th level, and a +3 item bonus at 17th level. If you have Siphoning Element class feature, you gain the Battle Medicine skill feat and can use your life powers to Treat Wounds and provide Battle Medicine with your powers and without a healer's kit; when you use Treat Wounds and Battle Medicine in this way, on a success the target recovers additional Hit Points equal to your level, and the target becomes temporarily immune to Battle Medicine for only 1 hour, not 1 day. At your GM's discretion, you can make other similar small adjustments to life force.

Elemental Resistance Your body becomes bolstered by life energy, protecting you from dying. If you fail a recovery check while dying, your dying condition does not increase; if you critically fail, your dying condition increases by only 1. If you have the Enhanced Resistance feat, you automatically critically succeed at all recovery checks.

Elemental Sculptor When you use the Elemental Sculptor feat, you can sculpt and control life force more easily than with Elemental Manipulation. You can use Elemental Sculptor to use any Medicine skill action that takes two actions or fewer, or Treat Wounds, at a range of 60 feet.

Elemental Senses You can sense the life force of living creatures nearby, and its counterforce within undead. You gain lifesense as an imprecise sense out to 30 feet.

Elemental Shield When the shield expires, recover Hit Points equal to half your level, or the amount of damage you took while the shield was active, whichever is less. This is a recovery effect.

Elemental Surge The chosen creature gains temporary Hit Points equal to your level for 1 round.

Enhanced Locomotion Your connection to your allies allows you to tap into their life force from a distance to bring yourself to their side. As a single action, which has the move trait, you can briefly transition into life energy and then reappear in a space adjacent to an ally within 60 feet. You still need line of effect to your ally and you either must be able to detect them with a precise sense or with imprecise lifesense, but you don't need to cross the intervening squares, allowing you to avoid obstacles and hazardous terrain, and this movement doesn't trigger reactions based on movement.

The life energies within you protect you from the forces of poison, death, and disease. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to saving throws against poison, death, and disease effects. If you roll a success on a saving throw against a death effect, you get a critical success instead.

Your wings might not be enough to fly, but they help you jump farther. You can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2HJ4yuEFY1Cast4h]{High Jump} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.JUvAvruz7yRQXfz2]{Long Jump} as a single action without a running start, and the distance is doubled (though this still doesn't allow you to jump farther than your Speed).

You send out glowing motes of healing energy, which latch onto your choice of either all living and undead creatures within a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30], or a single living or undead creature within 30 feet. If you target only a single creature, two motes latch onto that creature.

When a living creature with one or more motes takes damage, they receive an amount of simultaneous @Damage[(2+(2*@actor.level))[healing]]{healing} equal to 2 plus twice your level, up to a maximum of the damage taken, as normal for a recovery effect. One mote on the creature then vanishes.

When an undead creature with one or more motes takes damage, they also take @Damage[(2+(2*@actor.level))[vitality]] damage from the mote, and then one mote on the undead creature vanishes. Motes otherwise last until your next turn. Undead receive a @Check[type:reflex|dc:resolve(@actor.system.proficiencies.classDCs.eldamon.dc)] save to attempt to avoid the motes in the first place, with the following effects.

Critical Success The undead entirely avoids the mote.

Success The mote grazes the undead, and they take half the vitality damage from the mote.

Failure The mote attaches to the undead, and they take full damage from the mote.

Critical Failure The mote lands in an especially vulnerable spot for the undead, and they take double damage from the mote.

@UUID[Compendium.battlezoo-eldamon-pf2e.effects.Item.1gnFsjdwbgl3jYjT]{Effect: Healing Mote}

Level (+1) The damage increases by 2.

You send a powerful surge of vital essence into a creature within 30 feet, creating a life buffer that protects a living creature or damages an undead creature. If the target is a living creature, they gain 1d10 temporary Hit Points plus an additional 1d10 temporary Hit Points for each level you have. These temporary Hit Points last until you refresh.

If they're an undead creature, they instead take the same amount of @Damage[(1+@actor.level)d10[vitality]] damage with a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:resolve(@actor.system.proficiencies.classDCs.eldamon.dc)|basic:true] save.

@UUID[Compendium.battlezoo-eldamon-pf2e.effects.Item.p1FSamqUxqbkr1SV]{Effect: Life Buffer}

Level (+1) The damage increases by 1d10.

Trigger A foe damages an ally, and the ally is within 30 feet of you.

You connect your life force to your ally, protecting them from harm, though not without cost for yourself. You heal your ally simultaneously as they receive the damage, for @Damage[(1+@actor.level)[healing]], an amount equal to 1 plus your level, or the total damage, whichever is lower. This effectively reduces the total damage by that amount. If there is any damage remaining, you lose an amount of Hit Points equal to 1 plus your level, or the remaining damage, whichever is lower, and you further reduce the damage to your ally by that amount. Any damage that still remains applies to your ally as normal.

As you recalibrate the strands of vital essence all around you, you draw them all in toward yourself, weaving a cocoon of life energy and surrounding yourself. You are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} by the cocoon, but you gain temporary Hit Points equal to 3 plus three times your level, both lasting until the end of your next turn. You Refresh your powers.

If you lose all the temporary Hit Points, you are no longer immobilized, and if the immobilized condition ends or you move or are moved, the temporary Hit Points end. You can choose to end both the immobilized condition and temporary Hit Points as a free action, which has the concentrate trait.

Granted by @UUID[Compendium.battlezoo-eldamon-pf2e.eldamon-features.Item.QZgXHHRPN7XqpSvR]{Eldamon Battler}

All of your eldamon increase their maximum Hit Points by an amount equal to your level (minimum 2).

Note: Place this effect on each of your Eldamon actors

You can call forth your element to protect you from harm. You gain the @UUID[Compendium.battlezoo-eldamon-pf2e.actions.Item.g8lH9enxTY6Cpx9V]{Elemental Shield} action. When you use Elemental Shield, it gains your element's associated trait or traits. When you use Elemental Shield, you can increase the circumstance bonus from Elemental Shield to +2 if you choose to hold the elemental shield in a free hand.

You call forth your element to form a shield, which floats above you, or in your hand for increased protection. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to your AC until the beginning of your next turn from the elemental shield. You also gain the elemental shield benefit based on your element. If you use Elemental Shield again while your shield is still active, the previous shield ends and a new one appears.

Granted by @UUID[Compendium.battlezoo-eldamon-pf2e.feats.Item.6sAJu5oEkHWPdbwm]{Elemental Steps}

All your trained eldamon increase their Speeds by 5 feet. Additionally, they can Step into difficult terrain.

Note: Place this effect on each of your Eldamon actors

You train your eldamon friends to enhance their natural eldamon resistances, making it harder to overload them with their own element or overcome them with an elemental they already resist. Your eldamon increase their natural eldamon resistances based on their element from an amount equal to their level to an amount equal to one and a half times their level, starting at resistance 3 at 2nd level and ending at resistance 30 at 20th level.

Note: Place this feature on each of your Eldamon actors

Granted by @UUID[Compendium.battlezoo-eldamon-pf2e.feats.Item.YiWDPrJu3OAFrnTI]{Focused Training}

You train your eldamon friends to broaden their capacity for various skills. For each of your eldamon friends, choose for them to become brawny, burglarious, enthralling, nimble, self-sufficient, sneaky, or terrifying. If your eldamon already has the skill associated with the focused training you chose, your eldamon gains one of the skills associated with another focused training as an eldamon skill instead. Like their other eldamon skills, your eldamon become trained in the skill gained from focused training, and the skill increases to expert at 5th level and then to master at 11th level.

  • Self-Sufficient: Your eldamon can handle themself and can track creatures easily. They gain Survival as an eldamon skill and the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.urQZwmzg2kS53vd5]{Experienced Tracker} skill feat.

Note: Place this feature on your Eldamon actors

Tracking is second nature to you, and when necessary you can follow a trail without pause. You can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.EA5vuSgJfiHH7plD]{Track} while moving at full Speed by taking a –5 penalty to your Survival check. If you're a master in Survival, you don't take the –5 penalty. If you're legendary in Survival, you no longer need to roll a new Survival check every hour when tracking, though you still need to roll whenever there are significant changes in the trail.
